title: In the days of vinyl LP records, did anyone ever make a three-sided record? - Quora

response.answer_text: A three-sided record is physically impossible. I presume you mean a double album with audio on only three sides? Joe Jackson released a three-sided vinyl record in 1986. ‘Big World’ was a double album, but there was only music on Side One, Side Two, and Side Three. Side Four was blank, or ‘flat’ (I think that was the terminology for such records). It was his first album to be released in compact disc format. He knew he didn’t have to conform to the regular running time of a double vinyl album, so he only recorded enough music for three sides. I don’t own the vinyl version, but apparently the label states on Side Four: “There is no music on this side.” It does have a groove, and if you put the stylus in it, the stylus quickly moves to the end of the groove. Jackson is quoted as saying that the album doesn’t have a missing side - you get an extra side!

I remember a couple of oddities like that. Johnny Winter’s 1969 release “Second Winter” was a two-LP set with the fourth side blank. Monty Python’s 1973 “Matching Tie and Handkerchief” had for a limited time a “third side” contained within the grooves. On a related note…. A group called Sand had a unique two-LP issue for their 1973 release: one record had “Side 1” the second record had “Side 2” and the flip sides were blank. Most phonographs had a tall spindle so one could stack 45s or LPs and enjoy uninterrupted listening, as much as possible. The intention behind the design of the Sand album was one would stack both records and listen without having to flip sides.
